articles.headline: A College Financial Aid Guide for Families Who Have Saved Nothing
articles.snippet: Parents may panic when a child reaches senior year in high school and there’s little or no money for college available. Here are some options.
articles.abstract: Parents may panic when a child reaches senior year in high school and there’s little or no money for college available. Here are some options.
articles.lead_paragraph: A mother of five children in Bath, Me., admitted on the New York Times’s Motherlode blog earlier this year that she and her husband had no college savings. Their son, a high school junior, was about to leave for a college tour with some leftover Easter eggs for food, a tent and his one good pair of pants.

articles.headline: In Surprise, Top Lawyer at G.M. Sets Retirement
articles.snippet: Michael P. Millikin has been a central figure in G.M.’s safety crisis and a target of congressional critics.
articles.abstract: Michael P. Millikin has been a central figure in G.M.’s safety crisis and a target of congressional critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unexpected move, General Motors on Friday announced the retirement of its top lawyer, Michael P. Millikin, who has been a central figure in the automaker’s safety crisis and a target of congressional critics calling for broad reforms at the nation’s largest automaker.

articles.headline: Police Officer in Ferguson Is Said to Recount a Struggle
articles.snippet: The man who fatally shot a teenager in Missouri in August has told investigators that he feared for his life, according to officials.
articles.abstract: The man who fatally shot a teenager in Missouri in August has told investigators that he feared for his life, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., two months ago has told investigators that he was pinned in his vehicle and in fear for his life as he struggled over his gun with Mr. Brown, according to government officials briefed on the federal civil rights investigation into the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Matt Apuzzo and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Amid Assurances on Ebola, Obama Is Said to Seethe
articles.snippet: President Obama has assured the public that the government’s response was adequate. But he has also quietly faulted the handling as “not tight.”
articles.abstract: President Obama has assured the public that the government’s response was adequate. But he has also quietly faulted the handling as “not tight.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Beneath the calming reassurance that President Obama has repeatedly offered during the Ebola crisis, there is a deepening frustration, even anger, with how the government has handled key elements of the response.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Making Merkel Wait, Finding Time for Truffles
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin kept Chancellor Angela Merkel waiting for hours, met after 2 a.m. with Silvio Berlusconi, and joked at a news conference, but budged little on the Ukraine crisis.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin kept Chancellor Angela Merkel waiting for hours, met after 2 a.m. with Silvio Berlusconi, and joked at a news conference, but budged little on the Ukraine crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILAN — He was at it again this week.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Unable to Meet the Deductible or the Doctor
articles.snippet: Some people enrolled in private coverage through the Affordable Care Act are hesitating to use their insurance because of the high out-of-pocket costs.
articles.abstract: Some people enrolled in private coverage through the Affordable Care Act are hesitating to use their insurance because of the high out-of-pocket costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Patricia Wanderlich got insurance through the Affordable Care Act this year, and with good reason: She suffered a brain hemorrhage in 2011, spending weeks in a hospital intensive care unit, and has a second, smaller aneurysm that needs monitoring.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Heirs Sue Bank Over Sale of Nazi-Looted Art
articles.snippet: A lawsuit filed by members of the Kainer family contends that Swiss bank officials have not distributed money from sales of their relatives’ art that was looted by the Nazis.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit filed by members of the Kainer family contends that Swiss bank officials have not distributed money from sales of their relatives’ art that was looted by the Nazis.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Christie’s auctioned off Edgar Degas’s  “Danseuses” for nearly $11 million in 2009, the catalog noted that the masterpiece was being sold as part of a restitution agreement with the “heirs of Ludwig and Margret Kainer,” German Jews whose vast art collection was seized by the Nazis in the years leading up to World War II.

articles.headline: Behind Private Equity’s Curtain
articles.snippet: Public pensions have invested billions of dollars in buyout funds, but the terms — including some startling fees — are big secrets.
articles.abstract: Public pensions have invested billions of dollars in buyout funds, but the terms — including some startling fees — are big secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: From New York to California, Wisconsin to Texas, hundreds of thousands of teachers, firefighters, police officers and other public employees are relying on their pensions for financial security.

articles.headline: Life in Quarantine for Ebola Exposure: 21 Days of Fear and Loathing
articles.snippet: The number of people who have locked themselves away, either under government orders or voluntarily, has grown well beyond those who lived with and cared for the first Ebola victim in Dallas.
articles.abstract: The number of people who have locked themselves away, either under government orders or voluntarily, has grown well beyond those who lived with and cared for the first Ebola victim in Dallas.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The refrigerator in Youngor Jallah’s small apartment broke down last week, and it did not take long for the stench of rotting food to grow unbearable. But when she reported the problem to the front office, the complex’s manager said that a repairman would not be sent until Monday.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack, Jack Healy and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Of Virtue and Vice, and a Vatican Priest
articles.snippet: Accused of money laundering, Msgr. Nunzio Scarano said he was holding money for charity. But some see him as a symbol of a financial system gone awry.
articles.abstract: Accused of money laundering, Msgr. Nunzio Scarano said he was holding money for charity. But some see him as a symbol of a financial system gone awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a clear, warm day, a motorcycle zoomed through a quiet, narrow passageway in the old section of Salerno on Italy’s southwestern coast. The rider slowed in front of an elegant house with a baroque stone gate just long enough to shout “Thief! Thief!” before racing off.

articles.headline: Black Vote Seen as Last Hope for Democrats to Hold Senate
articles.snippet: Democrats are deploying black elected officials and others to target African-American voters, who could help swing midterm elections if they turn out in higher-than-forecast rates.
articles.abstract: Democrats are deploying black elected officials and others to target African-American voters, who could help swing midterm elections if they turn out in higher-than-forecast rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The confidential memo from a former pollster for President Obama contained a blunt warning for Democrats. Written this month with an eye toward Election Day, it predicted “crushing Democratic losses across the country” if the party did not do more to get black voters to the polls.

articles.headline: Mexico Finds Many Corpses, but Not Lost 43
articles.snippet: Residents of Iguala, Mexico, searching for students who disappeared after a clash with the police, have not found them, but they have found mass graves.
articles.abstract: Residents of Iguala, Mexico, searching for students who disappeared after a clash with the police, have not found them, but they have found mass graves.
articles.lead_paragraph: IGUALA, Mexico — With borrowed shovels and pick axes, the farmers drove their battered pickup trucks to a series of suspicious clearings in the countryside, jumped out and started digging.

articles.headline: Where Mud Is Archaeological Gold, Russian History Grew on Trees
articles.snippet: More than 1,000 birch-bark documents have been uncovered after being preserved for hundreds of years in the magical mud of Veliky Novgorod.
articles.abstract: More than 1,000 birch-bark documents have been uncovered after being preserved for hundreds of years in the magical mud of Veliky Novgorod.
articles.lead_paragraph: VELIKY NOVGOROD, Russia — The note, from father to son, was the sort of routine shopping list that today would be dashed off on a smartphone. In 14th century Russia, it was etched into the bark of a birch tree and curled into a scroll.

articles.headline: For South Korea, E-Sports Is National Pastime
articles.snippet: The extent to which video games have become part of mainstream culture in South Korea may be a sign of things to come in the West.
articles.abstract: The extent to which video games have become part of mainstream culture in South Korea may be a sign of things to come in the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Top video game players in South Korea are household names. Millions of people tune in to watch game competitions on television. The largest Internet portal, Naver, has its own section covering the results.

articles.headline: The Stream Finally Cracks the Dam of Cable TV
articles.snippet: Netflix, which was supposed to lay waste to traditional media companies, may have saved them instead.
articles.abstract: Netflix, which was supposed to lay waste to traditional media companies, may have saved them instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time I wrote about the traditional cable bundle — which has been so lucrative to networks like CBS and HBO — I warned that change comes very slowly, but then happens all at once.

articles.headline: Presumed Guilty in China’s War on Corruption, Targets Suffer Abuses
articles.snippet: China is in the midst of a scorching campaign against government corruption, but its system of investigation often operates in secret and beyond the law, leading to abuses suffered by the officials being targeted.
articles.abstract: China is in the midst of a scorching campaign against government corruption, but its system of investigation often operates in secret and beyond the law, leading to abuses suffered by the officials being targeted.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — He was starved, pummeled and interrogated for days on end in an ice-cold room where sleeping, sitting or even leaning against a wall were forbidden. One beating left Wang Guanglong, a midlevel official from China’s Fujian Province, partly deaf, according to his later testimony. Suicide, he told relatives and his lawyers afterward, tempted him.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Shouts on Bond-Trading Floor Yield to Robot Beeps
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase is moving more of its bond trading to electronic platforms, following a trend on Wall Street in stock trading, which was transformed by automation years ago.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase is moving more of its bond trading to electronic platforms, following a trend on Wall Street in stock trading, which was transformed by automation years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The face of automation on Wall Street is a computer hooked up to nine blinking screens that goes by the name Quantitative Market Maker, or Q.M.M.

articles.headline: For Aaron Kushner, a Difficult Foray Into Newspapers
articles.snippet: Aaron Kushner maintains that his Freedom Communications, parent of The Orange County Register and other papers, is on the road to success.
articles.abstract: Aaron Kushner maintains that his Freedom Communications, parent of The Orange County Register and other papers, is on the road to success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the entrepreneur Aaron Kushner bought into the newspaper business two years ago, he has generated a steady stream of headlines — about himself.

articles.headline: Before Bigger Stage, Walker Must Win Wisconsin
articles.snippet: Scott Walker’s job as governor is not all that is at stake: His currency as a presidential contender will surely vanish if he cannot win a second term.
articles.abstract: Scott Walker’s job as governor is not all that is at stake: His currency as a presidential contender will surely vanish if he cannot win a second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — In June 2012, the morning after Scott Walker became the first governor ever to survive a recall election, the talk of higher office began in earnest.

articles.headline: Phone Hackers Dial and Redial to Steal Billions
articles.snippet: A phone fraud on the rise and aided by Internet-connected phone systems can lead to six-figure bills for businesses.
articles.abstract: A phone fraud on the rise and aided by Internet-connected phone systems can lead to six-figure bills for businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Bob Foreman’s architecture firm ran up a $166,000 phone bill in a single weekend last March. But neither Mr. Foreman nor anyone else at his seven-person company was in the office at the time.

articles.headline: In U.S., Fear of Ebola Closes Schools and Shapes Politics
articles.snippet: Within the escalating debate over how to manage potential threats to public health, the line between vigilance and hysteria can be blurry.
articles.abstract: Within the escalating debate over how to manage potential threats to public health, the line between vigilance and hysteria can be blurry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the month since a Liberian man infected with Ebola traveled to Dallas, where he later died, the nation has marinated in a murky soup of understandable concern, wild misinformation, political opportunism and garden-variety panic.

articles.headline: In Homeland, Liberia Native Finds Resilience Amid Horror
articles.snippet: Long before Ebola arrived, the people of Liberia endured 14 years of civil war. When it finally ended in 2003, what was left was a nation of survivors.
articles.abstract: Long before Ebola arrived, the people of Liberia endured 14 years of civil war. When it finally ended in 2003, what was left was a nation of survivors.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Liberians have become accustomed to living with demons.

articles.headline: Volatility Unlikely to Alter Fed’s Policy Course
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve still plans to wrap up its bond-buying campaign at the end of October and remains likely to raise interest rates in mid-2015, although it now seems less likely to act sooner, analysts say.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve still plans to wrap up its bond-buying campaign at the end of October and remains likely to raise interest rates in mid-2015, although it now seems less likely to act sooner, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is watching carefully as financial markets bounce around, but the likely course of monetary policy remains the same, officials have said in recent public comments and interviews.

articles.headline: Weak Results at IBM as Its Strategy Shifts
articles.snippet: The chief executive called the results disappointing as the company said it would pay $1.5 billion to shed its chip-making unit.
articles.abstract: The chief executive called the results disappointing as the company said it would pay $1.5 billion to shed its chip-making unit.
articles.lead_paragraph: After IBM reported surprisingly weak quarterly profits and sales Monday morning, Virginia M. Rometty did something most unusual for an IBM chief executive. She joined the conference call with analysts, and forcefully made the case for investing heavily in new fields that promise growth in the future, despite a near-term financial setback.
